comment_text.dn32:1.1: This discourse bears similarities to the Mahāsamayasutta (DN 20). Thematically, that discourse is about the devotion of the deities, whereas this is about protection for the mendicants. | I believe this is only place in whole canon that lists the bhāṇavāra at the start.
comment_text.dn32:2.1: Here Kuvera is called Vessavaṇa, which our text below explains as being derived from the name of his city.
comment_text.dn32:3.1: “Protection” is rakkhā, which is a synonym of paritta.
comment_text.dn32:3.2: For these verses, I lean heavily on the translation by Ānandajoti, The Āṭānāṭiya Discourse. They are commonly recited in Theravada countries today. The recital begins with the seven Buddhas, for which see DN 14.
comment_text.dn32:3.14: Aṅgīras was one of the Vedic sages and the Aṅgīrasas are his descendants. They were priestly poets who assisted Indra in freeing the cows from the Vala cave, thus ushering in the dawn. Aṅgīras is regarded as the pravara or revered ancestor of the Gotama clan. Both names are associated with light: aṅgīrasa shares a root and is often synonymous with agni (“fire”), while gotama means “light dispelling dark”.
comment_text.dn32:4.1: Here begins a series of verses dedicated to the divinities in each of the four quarters, proceeding in the standard way: east, south, west, north.
comment_text.dn32:4.9: This is according to the commentary (taṁ rahadaṁ tattha evaṁ jānanti).
comment_text.dn32:4.29: This relates back to the basic problem facing the yakkhas: shame. They know what they do is wrong, but they like it and hence feel shame when hearing the Dhamma. But the Buddha treats them with respect, without shaming or bias, and thus is able to lead them to the good. The commentary implicitly connects this line with DN 30:2.1.2, where the Buddha “examines” (samekkhati) the population for their individual and shared traits.
comment_text.dn32:5.1: The south has the shortest and least auspicious description. To the extent that it relates to physical geography, this echoes the perception of northerners at the time that the south of India lay outside the “civilized” realms (āryāvarta).
comment_text.dn32:6.1: The description of the west mirrors the east.
comment_text.dn32:7.1: The description of the north is by far the most elaborate. | The “land north of Kuru” (uttarakuru) is mentioned in Sanskrit and Greek literature, where it sometimes appears as an actual country and other times as a place of fantasy. Attempts to locate it in a specific region in or beyond the Himalayas have proven inconclusive.
comment_text.dn32:7.2: Meru is another place that appears sometimes as a physical mountain and other times purely mystical. As home of the gods (Snp 3.11:4.3), its peak is accessible only by psychic powers (Thig 14.1:19.3, MN 50:30.1). It is the center of the world in Buddhist, Hindu, and Jain cosmologies. Today it is sometimes identified with Mount Kailash. See discussion of Sineru at SN 13.11:1.2.
comment_text.dn32:7.4: This agrees with the description at AN 9.21:1.3.
comment_text.dn32:7.7: They live in a kinder state of nature, which we selfish humans have lost (DN 27:16.1).
comment_text.dn32:7.11: Tuṇḍikīre is explained by the commentary as “firestone”. In the notes to his translation, Walshe suggests a relation with tandoor, which has been found as far back as the Indus Valley Civilization, a millennium before the Buddha.
comment_text.dn32:7.13: Cloven and uncloven was an important classification of animals in the Dharmaśāstras.
comment_text.dn32:7.17: The commentary says they were mostly carried on the backs of pregnant women(!). But the verb anuyanti indicates, rather, that they were “drawn along after”, which suggests a rickshaw.
comment_text.dn32:7.34: The discourse is named after the first of these cities. The name is hard to explain, but all the names in this series have the element nāṭa, which is probably the name of the people. One meaning of nāṭa is “dance”, and one of the unique features of this discourse is that each of the Four Great Kings is said to delight in song and dance. There is a long history of dancing divinities in India, and images of dancers go back as far as the Indus Valley Civilization. If we take nāṭa in the sense “the people of the dance”, kusināṭā would therefore be “dancers of the grass” after the kusa grass essential to the Vedic rites of kingship. Parakusināṭā is the “further dancers of the grass”, and parakusiṭanāṭā is probably a variation on that. Nāṭapuriyā is the “citadel of the dancers”. Each of these associates the people of the dance with the idea of protection or authority, agreeing with the context, where the cities are said to belong to a great king. Thus the prefix āṭā- probably stems from tāṇa (“shelter, refuge”; the same root as paritta), in the sense of the “refuge of the dancers”.
comment_text.dn32:7.35: Adopt the reading nāṭapuriyā found in Sinhalese-script manuscripts against the Mahāsaṅgīti’s nāṭasuriyā.
comment_text.dn32:7.38: Navanavutiya is “the city of the ninety-nine” i.e. three times thirty-three. | Ambara is “sky”.
comment_text.dn32:7.39: Also encountered at DN 17:1.3.8 and DN 16:5.18.5. Alakā is the capital of Kuvera in Sanskrit sources.
comment_text.dn32:7.41: The city Visāṇa is not encountered elsewhere, but it means “horn”, possibly reinforcing the importance of “song and dance”.
comment_text.dn32:7.44: The commentary explains “searching” (paccesanto) as investigating the meaning of the teachings. It takes pakāsenti as “explain”: the spirits of the nation explain the teaching to spirits who are gatekeepers, who then explain it to the king. The terms below are the names of these spirits. However, pakāsenti also means “shine”, and the names below seem to be associated with solar or celestial phenomena. I think the phrase is a poetic description of the celestial bodies that shine as they search across the sky. This verse is especially obscure, and any explanation is speculative, but below I offer an analysis under the assumption that the names depict shining celestial bodies.
comment_text.dn32:7.45: Resolve tatola as tato + la (= Sanskrit las, to shine or glitter): “one who glitters from afar”, i.e. a star that shines across the distant skies. | Tattala would then have tatta in the sense “heated”, i.e. “one who glitters from heat” (unless it is a misreading from tattha, yielding “one who glitters from there”). | Tatotala is a reduplicated form, “one who glitters from farther”.
comment_text.dn32:7.46: Take oja in the sense “lustre”—attested in Sanskrit but not otherwise in Pali—rather than the more familiar “nutritive essence” (MN 36:27.5), yielding “lustrous one”. | Tejasi means “brilliant one” (used of the sun at Praśna Upaniṣad 5.5). | Tatojasi means “one whose lustre shines from afar”.
comment_text.dn32:7.47: These are a set of associated solar names. Ariṭṭha and Nemi appear compounded in Sanskrit, Ariṣṭanemi, which evokes the powerful chariot of a conqueror (“indestructible rim”, Rig Veda 1.89.6, 1.180.10, 3.53.17, 10.178.1). It was the name of the 22nd Jain tīrthaṅkara, and in Brahmanical texts of several figures, including a dragon (Mahābhārata 1.59.39a, 1114.62a, etc.) and an Asura king (Bhāgavatapurāṇa 8.6.31, 8.10.10). Along with the divine steed Tārkṣya, he is associated with Garuḍa, and was probably originally an epithet for the unstoppable wheel of the Sun, Sūra. This line, then, while a simple list of four names in Pali, appears to be a fragmented memory of a Vedic conception which might be translated: “King Sun, (the wheel) of indestructible rim”.
comment_text.dn32:7.48: Dharaṇī the “bearer” is also a pregnant woman or Mother Earth.
comment_text.dn32:7.51: Sāla means “hall” or “sal tree”, but the commentary says it was surrounded by creepers of that name.
comment_text.dn32:7.59: Kuḷīrakā appears to be the name of a crab-eating bird (kuḷīra). In honor of my native country, I name it after the kookaburra, which eats crabs and is renowned for its cry.
comment_text.dn32:7.60: In Ja 547:426.2 we find koṭṭhā pokkharasātakā, where the koṭṭha is evidently a woodpecker. Satapatta can mean woodpecker or lotus (or crane or peacock), and perhaps there is an association here, the “hundred-leaved [bird] of the lotus pond”.
comment_text.dn32:10.2: For these gods, see my comment on DN 13:25.2. Here I will comment on the names not discussed elsewhere, especially in DN 20.
comment_text.dn32:10.3: This is presumably Bharadvāja Bārhaspatya, the rishi ancestor of the Bhāradvāja clan, many members of which are encountered in the suttas. It is unusual to find him listed along with the primary Vedic gods. The Bhāradvāja verses are mostly collected in the sixth book of the Rig Veda, where they show a special devotion to the god Pūṣan. See also note on SN 7.1:1.2.
comment_text.dn32:10.11: These deities appear nowhere else. Puṇṇaka is “full”, guḷa is “lump”, and karatiya is unclear (“bean-like”?).
comment_text.dn32:10.12: The yakkha Sivaka (“blissful, auspicious”) helped Anāthapiṇḍika visit the Buddha (SN 10.8:1.12); he is possibly to be identified with Shiva. | The dragon king Mucalinda sheltered the Buddha after his awakening (Ud 2.1:2.2).
comment_text.dn32:10.13: Yugandhara is the tutelary deity of the mountain of that name.
comment_text.dn32:10.14: Gopāla is “cowherd”, an epithet of both Krishna and Shiva.| Suppagedha (or supparodha) is obscure.
comment_text.dn32:10.16: A saying by Pañcālacaṇḍa at SN 2.7 is quoted by Udāyī and explained by Ānanda at AN 9.42. He would appear to be the fierce (caṇḍa) protector of the Pañcāla clan, but a Pañcālacanda appears as a brahmin teacher (Aitereya Āraṇyaka 3.1.6, Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka 7.19, Gopatha Brāhmaṇa 1.1.27n). | Āḷavaka is the tutelary deity of Āḷavī (SN 10.12, Snp 1.10).
comment_text.dn32:10.17: Pajjuna is Parjanya, the Vedic god of rain, especially the thunderstorm. His daughters appear in SN 1.39 and SN 1.40. | Sumana is “Happyheart”, sumukha is “Fairface”.
comment_text.dn32:10.18: Dadhimukha is “Milkface”, and in the Mahābhārata is a name of a dragon. | Maṇi is “gem”. | Māṇivara is “fine gem”, although the commentary takes this as two names. | Dīgha is identified by the commentary with Dīgha Parajana of MN 31:21.1.
comment_text.dn32:10.19: Serīsaka means “of sirīsa wood”, perhaps the tutelary deity of a forest.

root_text.dn32:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
root_text.dn32:1.3: Atha kho cattāro mahārājā mahatiyā ca yakkhasenāya mahatiyā ca gandhabbasenāya mahatiyā ca kumbhaṇḍasenāya mahatiyā ca nāgasenāya catuddisaṁ rakkhaṁ ṭhapetvā catuddisaṁ gumbaṁ ṭhapetvā catuddisaṁ ovaraṇaṁ ṭhapetvā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṁ gijjhakūṭaṁ pabbataṁ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
root_text.dn32:1.4: Tepi kho yakkhā appekacce bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu, appekacce bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu, sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu, appekacce yena bhagavā tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu, appekacce nāmagottaṁ sāvetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu, appekacce tuṇhībhūtā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
root_text.dn32:2.1: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho vessavaṇo mahārājā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn32:2.2: “santi hi, bhante, uḷārā yakkhā bhagavato appasannā.
root_text.dn32:2.3: Santi hi, bhante, uḷārā yakkhā bhagavato pasannā.
root_text.dn32:2.4: Santi hi, bhante, majjhimā yakkhā bhagavato appasannā.
root_text.dn32:2.5: Santi hi, bhante, majjhimā yakkhā bhagavato pasannā.
root_text.dn32:2.6: Santi hi, bhante, nīcā yakkhā bhagavato appasannā.
root_text.dn32:2.7: Santi hi, bhante, nīcā yakkhā bhagavato pasannā.
root_text.dn32:2.8: Yebhuyyena kho pana, bhante, yakkhā appasannāyeva bhagavato.
root_text.dn32:2.10: Bhagavā hi, bhante, pāṇātipātā veramaṇiyā dhammaṁ deseti, adinnādānā veramaṇiyā dhammaṁ deseti, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇiyā dhammaṁ deseti, musāvādā veramaṇiyā dhammaṁ deseti, surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānā veramaṇiyā dhammaṁ deseti.
root_text.dn32:2.11: Yebhuyyena kho pana, bhante, yakkhā appaṭiviratāyeva pāṇātipātā, appaṭiviratā adinnādānā, appaṭiviratā kāmesumicchācārā, appaṭiviratā musāvādā, appaṭiviratā surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānā.
root_text.dn32:2.13: Santi hi, bhante, bhagavato sāvakā araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevanti appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni.
root_text.dn32:2.14: Tattha santi uḷārā yakkhā nivāsino, ye imasmiṁ bhagavato pāvacane appasannā.
root_text.dn32:2.15: Tesaṁ pasādāya uggaṇhātu, bhante, bhagavā āṭānāṭiyaṁ rakkhaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ upāsakānaṁ upāsikānaṁ guttiyā rakkhāya avihiṁsāya phāsuvihārāyā”ti.
root_text.dn32:3.1: Atha kho vessavaṇo mahārājā bhagavato adhivāsanaṁ viditvā tāyaṁ velāyaṁ imaṁ āṭānāṭiyaṁ rakkhaṁ abhāsi:
root_text.dn32:8.1: Ayaṁ kho sā, mārisa, āṭānāṭiyā rakkhā bhikkhūnaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ upāsakānaṁ upāsikānaṁ guttiyā rakkhāya avihiṁsāya phāsuvihārāya.
root_text.dn32:8.2: Yassa kassaci, mārisa, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā upāsakassa vā upāsikāya vā ayaṁ āṭānāṭiyā rakkhā suggahitā bhavissati samattā pariyāputā.
root_text.dn32:8.3: Tañce amanusso yakkho vā yakkhinī vā yakkhapotako vā yakkhapotikā vā yakkhamahāmatto vā yakkhapārisajjo vā yakkhapacāro vā, gandhabbo vā gandhabbī vā gandhabbapotako vā gandhabbapotikā vā gandhabbamahāmatto vā gandhabbapārisajjo vā gandhabbapacāro vā, kumbhaṇḍo vā kumbhaṇḍī vā kumbhaṇḍapotako vā kumbhaṇḍapotikā vā kumbhaṇḍamahāmatto vā kumbhaṇḍapārisajjo vā kumbhaṇḍapacāro vā, nāgo vā nāgī vā nāgapotako vā nāgapotikā vā nāgamahāmatto vā nāgapārisajjo vā nāgapacāro vā, paduṭṭhacitto bhikkhuṁ vā bhikkhuniṁ vā upāsakaṁ vā upāsikaṁ vā gacchantaṁ vā anugaccheyya, ṭhitaṁ vā upatiṭṭheyya, nisinnaṁ vā upanisīdeyya, nipannaṁ vā upanipajjeyya.
root_text.dn32:8.4: Na me so, mārisa, amanusso labheyya gāmesu vā nigamesu vā sakkāraṁ vā garukāraṁ vā.
root_text.dn32:8.5: Na me so, mārisa, amanusso labheyya āḷakamandāya nāma rājadhāniyā vatthuṁ vā vāsaṁ vā.
root_text.dn32:8.6: Na me so, mārisa, amanusso labheyya yakkhānaṁ samitiṁ gantuṁ.
root_text.dn32:8.7: Apissu naṁ, mārisa, amanussā anāvayhampi naṁ kareyyuṁ avivayhaṁ.
root_text.dn32:8.8: Apissu naṁ, mārisa, amanussā attāhipi paripuṇṇāhi paribhāsāhi paribhāseyyuṁ.
root_text.dn32:8.9: Apissu naṁ, mārisa, amanussā rittampissa pattaṁ sīse nikkujjeyyuṁ.
root_text.dn32:8.10: Apissu naṁ, mārisa, amanussā sattadhāpissa muddhaṁ phāleyyuṁ.
root_text.dn32:9.1: Santi hi, mārisa, amanussā caṇḍā ruddhā rabhasā, te neva mahārājānaṁ ādiyanti, na mahārājānaṁ purisakānaṁ ādiyanti, na mahārājānaṁ purisakānaṁ purisakānaṁ ādiyanti.
root_text.dn32:9.2: Te kho te, mārisa, amanussā mahārājānaṁ avaruddhā nāma vuccanti.
root_text.dn32:9.3: Seyyathāpi, mārisa, rañño māgadhassa vijite mahācorā.
root_text.dn32:9.4: Te neva rañño māgadhassa ādiyanti, na rañño māgadhassa purisakānaṁ ādiyanti, na rañño māgadhassa purisakānaṁ purisakānaṁ ādiyanti.
root_text.dn32:9.5: Te kho te, mārisa, mahācorā rañño māgadhassa avaruddhā nāma vuccanti.
root_text.dn32:9.6: Evameva kho, mārisa, santi amanussā caṇḍā ruddhā rabhasā, te neva mahārājānaṁ ādiyanti, na mahārājānaṁ purisakānaṁ ādiyanti, na mahārājānaṁ purisakānaṁ purisakānaṁ ādiyanti.
root_text.dn32:9.7: Te kho te, mārisa, amanussā mahārājānaṁ avaruddhā nāma vuccanti.
root_text.dn32:9.8: Yo hi koci, mārisa, amanusso yakkho vā yakkhinī vā …pe… gandhabbo vā gandhabbī vā …pe… kumbhaṇḍo vā kumbhaṇḍī vā …pe… nāgo vā nāgī vā nāgapotako vā nāgapotikā vā nāgamahāmatto vā nāgapārisajjo vā nāgapacāro vā paduṭṭhacitto bhikkhuṁ vā bhikkhuniṁ vā upāsakaṁ vā upāsikaṁ vā gacchantaṁ vā anugaccheyya, ṭhitaṁ vā upatiṭṭheyya, nisinnaṁ vā upanisīdeyya, nipannaṁ vā upanipajjeyya.
root_text.dn32:9.9: Imesaṁ yakkhānaṁ mahāyakkhānaṁ senāpatīnaṁ mahāsenāpatīnaṁ ujjhāpetabbaṁ vikkanditabbaṁ viravitabbaṁ:
root_text.dn32:9.10: ‘ayaṁ yakkho gaṇhāti, ayaṁ yakkho āvisati, ayaṁ yakkho heṭheti, ayaṁ yakkho viheṭheti, ayaṁ yakkho hiṁsati, ayaṁ yakkho vihiṁsati, ayaṁ yakkho na muñcatī’ti.
root_text.dn32:10.20: Imesaṁ yakkhānaṁ mahāyakkhānaṁ senāpatīnaṁ mahāsenāpatīnaṁ ujjhāpetabbaṁ vikkanditabbaṁ viravitabbaṁ:
root_text.dn32:10.21: ‘ayaṁ yakkho gaṇhāti, ayaṁ yakkho āvisati, ayaṁ yakkho heṭheti, ayaṁ yakkho viheṭheti, ayaṁ yakkho hiṁsati, ayaṁ yakkho vihiṁsati, ayaṁ yakkho na muñcatī’ti.
root_text.dn32:11.1: Ayaṁ kho sā, mārisa, āṭānāṭiyā rakkhā bhikkhūnaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ upāsakānaṁ upāsikānaṁ guttiyā rakkhāya avihiṁsāya phāsuvihārāya.
root_text.dn32:11.2: Handa ca dāni mayaṁ, mārisa, gacchāma bahukiccā mayaṁ bahukaraṇīyā”ti.
root_text.dn32:11.4: Atha kho cattāro mahārājā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā tatthevantaradhāyiṁsu.
root_text.dn32:11.5: Tepi kho yakkhā uṭṭhāyāsanā appekacce bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā tatthevantaradhāyiṁsu. Appekacce bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu, sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā tatthevantaradhāyiṁsu. Appekacce yena bhagavā tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā tatthevantaradhāyiṁsu. Appekacce nāmagottaṁ sāvetvā tatthevantaradhāyiṁsu. Appekacce tuṇhībhūtā tatthevantaradhāyiṁsūti.
root_text.dn32:12.1: Atha kho bhagavā tassā rattiyā accayena bhikkhū āmantesi:
root_text.dn32:12.2: “imaṁ, bhikkhave, rattiṁ cattāro mahārājā mahatiyā ca yakkhasenāya mahatiyā ca gandhabbasenāya mahatiyā ca kumbhaṇḍasenāya mahatiyā ca nāgasenāya catuddisaṁ rakkhaṁ ṭhapetvā catuddisaṁ gumbaṁ ṭhapetvā catuddisaṁ ovaraṇaṁ ṭhapetvā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṁ gijjhakūṭaṁ pabbataṁ obhāsetvā yenāhaṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā maṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
root_text.dn32:12.3: Tepi kho, bhikkhave, yakkhā appekacce maṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Appekacce mayā saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu, sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Appekacce yenāhaṁ tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Appekacce nāmagottaṁ sāvetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Appekacce tuṇhībhūtā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
root_text.dn32:12.4: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho, bhikkhave, vessavaṇo mahārājā maṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn32:12.5: ‘santi hi, bhante, uḷārā yakkhā bhagavato appasannā …pe… santi hi, bhante, nīcā yakkhā bhagavato pasannā.
root_text.dn32:12.6: Yebhuyyena kho pana, bhante, yakkhā appasannāyeva bhagavato.
root_text.dn32:12.8: Bhagavā hi, bhante, pāṇātipātā veramaṇiyā dhammaṁ deseti … surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānā veramaṇiyā dhammaṁ deseti.
root_text.dn32:12.9: Yebhuyyena kho pana, bhante, yakkhā appaṭiviratāyeva pāṇātipātā … appaṭiviratā surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānā.
root_text.dn32:12.11: Santi hi, bhante, bhagavato sāvakā araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevanti appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni.
root_text.dn32:12.12: Tattha santi uḷārā yakkhā nivāsino, ye imasmiṁ bhagavato pāvacane appasannā, tesaṁ pasādāya uggaṇhātu, bhante, bhagavā āṭānāṭiyaṁ rakkhaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ upāsakānaṁ upāsikānaṁ guttiyā rakkhāya avihiṁsāya phāsuvihārāyā’ti.
root_text.dn32:12.14: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vessavaṇo mahārājā me adhivāsanaṁ viditvā tāyaṁ velāyaṁ imaṁ āṭānāṭiyaṁ rakkhaṁ abhāsi:
root_text.dn32:12.231: Ayaṁ kho sā, mārisa, āṭānāṭiyā rakkhā bhikkhūnaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ upāsakānaṁ upāsikānaṁ guttiyā rakkhāya avihiṁsāya phāsuvihārāya.
root_text.dn32:12.232: Yassa kassaci, mārisa, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā upāsakassa vā upāsikāya vā ayaṁ āṭānāṭiyā rakkhā suggahitā bhavissati samattā pariyāputā tañce amanusso yakkho vā yakkhinī vā …pe… gandhabbo vā gandhabbī vā …pe… kumbhaṇḍo vā kumbhaṇḍī vā …pe… nāgo vā nāgī vā nāgapotako vā nāgapotikā vā nāgamahāmatto vā nāgapārisajjo vā nāgapacāro vā, paduṭṭhacitto bhikkhuṁ vā bhikkhuniṁ vā upāsakaṁ vā upāsikaṁ vā gacchantaṁ vā anugaccheyya, ṭhitaṁ vā upatiṭṭheyya, nisinnaṁ vā upanisīdeyya, nipannaṁ vā upanipajjeyya.
root_text.dn32:12.233: Na me so, mārisa, amanusso labheyya gāmesu vā nigamesu vā sakkāraṁ vā garukāraṁ vā.
root_text.dn32:12.234: Na me so, mārisa, amanusso labheyya āḷakamandāya nāma rājadhāniyā vatthuṁ vā vāsaṁ vā.
root_text.dn32:12.235: Na me so, mārisa, amanusso labheyya yakkhānaṁ samitiṁ gantuṁ.
root_text.dn32:12.236: Apissu naṁ, mārisa, amanussā anāvayhampi naṁ kareyyuṁ avivayhaṁ.
root_text.dn32:12.237: Apissu naṁ, mārisa, amanussā attāhi paripuṇṇāhi paribhāsāhi paribhāseyyuṁ.
root_text.dn32:12.238: Apissu naṁ, mārisa, amanussā rittampissa pattaṁ sīse nikkujjeyyuṁ.
root_text.dn32:12.239: Apissu naṁ, mārisa, amanussā sattadhāpissa muddhaṁ phāleyyuṁ.
root_text.dn32:12.240: Santi hi, mārisa, amanussā caṇḍā ruddhā rabhasā, te neva mahārājānaṁ ādiyanti, na mahārājānaṁ purisakānaṁ ādiyanti, na mahārājānaṁ purisakānaṁ purisakānaṁ ādiyanti.
root_text.dn32:12.241: Te kho te, mārisa, amanussā mahārājānaṁ avaruddhā nāma vuccanti.
root_text.dn32:12.242: Seyyathāpi, mārisa, rañño māgadhassa vijite mahācorā.
root_text.dn32:12.243: Te neva rañño māgadhassa ādiyanti, na rañño māgadhassa purisakānaṁ ādiyanti, na rañño māgadhassa purisakānaṁ purisakānaṁ ādiyanti.
root_text.dn32:12.244: Te kho te, mārisa, mahācorā rañño māgadhassa avaruddhā nāma vuccanti.
root_text.dn32:12.245: Evameva kho, mārisa, santi amanussā caṇḍā ruddhā rabhasā, te neva mahārājānaṁ ādiyanti, na mahārājānaṁ purisakānaṁ ādiyanti, na mahārājānaṁ purisakānaṁ purisakānaṁ ādiyanti.
root_text.dn32:12.246: Te kho te, mārisa, amanussā mahārājānaṁ avaruddhā nāma vuccanti.
root_text.dn32:12.247: Yo hi koci, mārisa, amanusso yakkho vā yakkhinī vā …pe… gandhabbo vā gandhabbī vā …pe… kumbhaṇḍo vā kumbhaṇḍī vā …pe… nāgo vā nāgī vā …pe… paduṭṭhacitto bhikkhuṁ vā bhikkhuniṁ vā upāsakaṁ vā upāsikaṁ vā gacchantaṁ vā upagaccheyya, ṭhitaṁ vā upatiṭṭheyya, nisinnaṁ vā upanisīdeyya, nipannaṁ vā upanipajjeyya.
root_text.dn32:12.248: Imesaṁ yakkhānaṁ mahāyakkhānaṁ senāpatīnaṁ mahāsenāpatīnaṁ ujjhāpetabbaṁ vikkanditabbaṁ viravitabbaṁ:
root_text.dn32:12.249: “ayaṁ yakkho gaṇhāti, ayaṁ yakkho āvisati, ayaṁ yakkho heṭheti, ayaṁ yakkho viheṭheti, ayaṁ yakkho hiṁsati, ayaṁ yakkho vihiṁsati, ayaṁ yakkho na muñcatī”ti.
root_text.dn32:12.269: Imesaṁ yakkhānaṁ mahāyakkhānaṁ senāpatīnaṁ mahāsenāpatīnaṁ ujjhāpetabbaṁ vikkanditabbaṁ viravitabbaṁ:
root_text.dn32:12.270: “ayaṁ yakkho gaṇhāti, ayaṁ yakkho āvisati, ayaṁ yakkho heṭheti, ayaṁ yakkho viheṭheti, ayaṁ yakkho hiṁsati, ayaṁ yakkho vihiṁsati, ayaṁ yakkho na muñcatī”ti.
root_text.dn32:12.271: Ayaṁ kho, mārisa, āṭānāṭiyā rakkhā bhikkhūnaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ upāsakānaṁ upāsikānaṁ guttiyā rakkhāya avihiṁsāya phāsuvihārāya.
root_text.dn32:12.272: Handa ca dāni mayaṁ, mārisa, gacchāma, bahukiccā mayaṁ bahukaraṇīyā’ti.
root_text.dn32:12.274: Atha kho, bhikkhave, cattāro mahārājā uṭṭhāyāsanā maṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā tatthevantaradhāyiṁsu.
root_text.dn32:12.275: Tepi kho, bhikkhave, yakkhā uṭṭhāyāsanā appekacce maṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā tatthevantaradhāyiṁsu.
root_text.dn32:12.276: Appekacce mayā saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu, sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā tatthevantaradhāyiṁsu.
root_text.dn32:13.4: Atthasaṁhitā, bhikkhave, āṭānāṭiyā rakkhā bhikkhūnaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ upāsakānaṁ upāsikānaṁ guttiyā rakkhāya avihiṁsāya phāsuvihārāyā”ti.
root_text.dn32:13.6: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.dn32:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
translation_text.dn32:1.3: Then, late at night, the four great kings—with large armies of spirits, centaurs, gnomes, and dragons—set guards, troops, and wards at the four quarters and then, lighting up the entire Vulture’s Peak with their beauty, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
translation_text.dn32:1.4: Before sitting down to one side, some spirits bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.
translation_text.dn32:2.1: Seated to one side, the Great King Vessavaṇa said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn32:2.2: “Sir, some high spirits have confidence in the Buddha,
translation_text.dn32:2.4: Some middling spirits have confidence in the Buddha,
translation_text.dn32:2.6: Some low spirits have confidence in the Buddha,
translation_text.dn32:2.8: But mostly the spirits don’t have confidence in the Buddha.
translation_text.dn32:2.10: Because the Buddha teaches them to refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, lying, sexual misconduct, and consuming beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.
translation_text.dn32:2.11: But mostly they don’t refrain from such things.
translation_text.dn32:2.12: They don’t like that or approve of it.
translation_text.dn32:2.13: Sir, there are disciples of the Buddha who frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest that are quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat.
translation_text.dn32:2.14: There dwell high spirits who have no confidence in the Buddha’s dispensation.
translation_text.dn32:2.15: To give them confidence, may the Buddha please learn the Āṭānāṭiya protection for the guarding, protection, safety, and comfort of the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.”
translation_text.dn32:3.1: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, on that occasion Great King Vessavaṇa recited the Āṭānāṭiya protection.

translation_text.dn32:8.1: This, good fellow, is the Āṭānāṭiya protection for the guarding, protection, safety, and comfort of the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.
translation_text.dn32:8.2: The monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen should learn this Āṭānāṭiya protection well and completely memorize it.
translation_text.dn32:8.3: If anyone who does so is approached while walking, standing, sitting, or lying down by any non-human being with malicious intent—including males, females, boys, girls, chief ministers, councillors, and servants among the spirits, centaurs, gnomes, and dragons—
translation_text.dn32:8.4: that non-human will receive no homage or respect in any village or town.
translation_text.dn32:8.5: And they will receive no ground or dwelling in my capital of Ālakamandā.
translation_text.dn32:8.6: Nor will they get to go to the conference of the spirits.
translation_text.dn32:8.7: In addition, the non-humans would not give or take them in marriage.
translation_text.dn32:8.8: They’d heap personal abuse on them,
translation_text.dn32:8.9: drop an empty bowl on their head,
translation_text.dn32:8.10: and even split their head into seven pieces!
translation_text.dn32:9.1: For there are, good fellow, non-humans who are fierce, cruel, and violent. They don’t obey the Great Kings or their men or their men’s men.
translation_text.dn32:9.2: They’re said to be rebelling against the Great Kings.
translation_text.dn32:9.3: They’re just like the bandits in the king of Magadha’s realm
translation_text.dn32:9.4: who don’t obey the king, his men, or his men’s men,
translation_text.dn32:9.5: and are said to be rebelling against the king.
translation_text.dn32:9.8: If any non-human being with malicious intent—including males, females, boys, girls, ministers, councillors, and servants among the spirits, centaurs, gnomes, and dragons—approaches a monk, nun, layman, or laywoman while walking, standing, sitting, or lying down,
translation_text.dn32:9.9: one ought to yell, cry, and scream to the spirits, great spirits, generals, great generals:
translation_text.dn32:9.10: ‘This spirit’s got me! This spirit’s entered me! This spirit’s annoying me! This spirit’s harassing me! This spirit’s hurting me! This spirit’s harming me! This spirit won’t let me go!’
translation_text.dn32:10.1: To what spirits, great spirits, generals, great generals?
translation_text.dn32:10.9: and the kings Nala and Janesabha,
translation_text.dn32:11.1: This, good fellow, is the Āṭānāṭiya protection for the guarding, protection, safety, and comfort of the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.
translation_text.dn32:11.2: Well, now, good fellow, I must go. I have many duties, and much to do.”
translation_text.dn32:11.3: “Please, Great Kings, go at your convenience.”
translation_text.dn32:11.4: Then the four great kings got up from their seats, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right side, before vanishing right there.
translation_text.dn32:11.5: And before the other spirits present vanished, some bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right side, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.
translation_text.dn32:11.6: The first recitation section is finished.
translation_text.dn32:12.1: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened, repeating all the verses spoken. Then he added:
translation_text.dn32:13.4: The Āṭānāṭiya protection is beneficial, and is for the guarding, protection, safety, and comfort of the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.”
translation_text.dn32:13.5: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.dn32:13.6: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
